an9.72:1.1: “Mendicants, there are these five emotional shackles.
an9.72:1.3: Firstly, a mendicant isn’t free of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures.
an9.72:1.4: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.
an9.72:1.5: This is the first emotional shackle.
an9.72:2.1: Furthermore, a mendicant isn’t free of greed for the body …
an9.72:2.2: They’re not free of greed for form …
an9.72:2.3: They eat as much as they like until their belly is full, then indulge in the pleasures of sleeping, lying down, and drowsing …
an9.72:2.4: They lead the spiritual life wishing to be reborn in one of the orders of gods: ‘By this precept or observance or fervent austerity or spiritual life, may I become one of the gods!’
an9.72:2.5: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.
an9.72:2.6: This is the fifth emotional shackle.
an9.72:2.7: These are the five emotional shackles.
an9.72:3.1: To give up these five emotional shackles you should develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
an9.72:3.3: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
an9.72:3.4: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …
an9.72:3.5: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind …
an9.72:3.6: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
an9.72:3.7: To give up these five emotional shackles you should develop these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.”
